title: 112_hr4119
content: The "Border Tunnel Prevention Act of 2012" aims to address the increasing use of tunnels by trafficking organizations to enter the United States from Mexico. Law enforcement has discovered 149 cross-border tunnels between Mexico and the US from Fiscal Year 1990 to 2011, with a significant increase in Arizona and California since 2006. Since Fiscal Year 2006, 40 tunnels have been discovered in California and 74 in Arizona. The Department of Homeland Security Appropriations Act of 2007 criminalizes unauthorized tunnel construction or financing across the US border. Anyone convicted of using a tunnel for smuggling faces enhanced sentencing. SEC. 3. ATTEMPT OR CONSPIRACY TO USE, CONSTRUCT, OR FINANCE A BORDER TUNNEL. Any person attempting or conspiring to commit offenses related to border tunnel construction will face the same penalties as those prescribed for the actual offense. SEC. 4. AUTHORIZATION FOR INTERCEPTION OF WIRE, ORAL, OR ELECTRONIC COMMUNICATIONS. Title 18 of the United States Code is amended to allow interception of communications related to border tunnel construction. SEC. 5. FORFEITURE. Amendments to Title 18 allow for forfeiture of assets related to border tunnel activities. SEC. 6. MONEY LAUNDERING DESIGNATION. Section 1956(c)(7)(D) of title 18, United States Code, is amended by inserting "section 555 (relating to border tunnels)," after "section 554 (relating to smuggling goods from the United States)." SEC. 7. SENSE OF CONGRESS. Congress emphasizes the need for cooperation between various officials and private landowners to combat cross-border tunnels, with the Department of Homeland Security engaging in outreach efforts in California for assistance. The Department should continue outreach efforts to landowners in high cross-border tunnel areas. The Secretary of Homeland Security must report annually on discovered tunnels and Department needs for prevention and prosecution. Congressional committees overseeing this include the Senate's Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs. The Senate and House committees overseeing the Department of Homeland Security's efforts on cross-border tunnels include the Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs, the Committee on the Judiciary, and the Committee on Appropriations. The curr_chunk is about the roles of the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the Vice President of the United States as President of the Senate.
